Dr. Emily Carter, Dr. Mark Chen
Identify and manage Kawasaki disease in a pediatric patient.
Kawasaki disease is a leading cause of acquired heart disease in children; prompt recognition and treatment are critical.
You are in the pediatric emergency department when a worried mother brings in her 5-year-old son, who has had a fever for 5 days and developed a rash.
Management of a pediatric patient with fever and rash suggestive of Kawasaki disease.
Brightly lit pediatric emergency room with medical equipment and a concerned mother.
Monitor alarms, nurse chatter, distant voices
5-year-old boy with rash and fever, mother looking anxious.
Patient presents with fever lasting 5 days, rash, and conjunctivitis.
Patient on monitor for heart rate and oxygen saturation.
If untreated â†’ myocardial complications; else â†’ treat with IVIG.
>5 min no action â†’ worsening fever; >10 min â†’ potential cardiac involvement.
Fever, rash, conjunctivitis, swollen lymph nodes.
Kawasaki disease, fever, rash, pediatric emergency
{"If given IVIG": "Fever resolves over 24h", "If untreated >10min": "Increased risk for cardiac complications"}
Branch: if IVIG administered â†’ monitor for improvement; else â†’ prepare for possible transfer.
Start IV fluids, order labs, consult pediatrics.
Administer IVIG, monitor vital signs closely.
Prepare for possible cardiac evaluation, escalate care.
ECG shows tachycardia, no ischemic changes.
Demonstrate recognition and management of Kawasaki disease in children.
What is the first-line treatment for Kawasaki disease?
Created to enhance pediatric emergency training focusing on Kawasaki disease.

Acute Myocardial Infarction (55 M): Rapid Response Saves Lives
Acute MI Management â”‚ Â© 2023 EM Sim Cases (CC BY-SA 4.0)

{"sbarHandoff":"EMS arrives with a 55-year-old male clutching his chest, sweating profusely. He complains of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. Vitals are unstable and he appears pale.","theStakes":"Intervention within the next 10 minutes is crucial to prevent cardiac arrest.","mysteryHook":"Initial interventions may seem straightforward but require rapid decision-making under pressure.","whatYouWillLearn":["Identifying signs of myocardial infarction","Administering life-saving interventions","Coordinating with cardiology for rapid response"],"estimatedTime":"5-10 minutes","caseId":"CARD0045","type":"pre-sim","aiGenerated":true,"model":"gpt-4o","timestamp":"2025-11-02T20:10:12.000Z"}

{"victoryHeadline":"ðŸŽ‰ Case Mastered: Cardiac Intervention Pro!","patientStoryAnchor":"The 55-year-old businessman who was rushed into ER with excruciating chest pain, his life hanging by a thread.","celebrationOpening":"Congratulations! Your decisive actions have navigated this high-stakes cardiac emergency, ensuring the patient received timely interventions that saved his life.","theCriticalPearl":{"title":"The Heart of the Matter","content":"In cases of suspected myocardial infarction, rapid administration of aspirin and initiation of reperfusion therapy is vital.","memoryAid":"Remember 'TIME IS MUSCLE' â€“ act swiftly to preserve heart function."},"whatYouMastered":["Before: Uncertain about MI protocols â†’ After: Confident in initiating rapid MI interventions","Recognizing EKG changes indicative of MI under pressure","Implementing timely and effective cardiac care"],"avoidTheseTraps":["Delaying EKG and reperfusion can lead to irreversible damage.","Overlooking atypical symptoms can delay diagnosis and treatment."],"realWorldImpact":{"patientSafety":"Your rapid intervention reduces mortality in myocardial infarction cases, turning potential fatalities into recoveries.","careerProtection":"Mastering these skills protects your career by ensuring best-practice patient care, reducing risk of litigation.","clinicalConfidence":"This experience boosts your confidence and expertise in managing cardiac emergencies."},"nextSteps":{"inThisPathway":"Proceed to 'Complex Arrhythmias Management' in the Cardiac Care Mastery pathway.","toReinforce":"Review EKG interpretation and participate in cardiac arrest simulations to solidify this knowledge."},"rememberForever":"In myocardial infarction, act fast: administer aspirin and organize reperfusion therapy.","confidence":0.96,"caseId":"CARD0045","revealTitle":"Acute Myocardial Infarction (55 M): Rapid Response Saves Lives","type":"post-sim","aiGenerated":true,"model":"gpt-4o","timestamp":"2025-11-02T20:10:15.000Z"}
Dr. Sarah Kim, Dr. John Doe
Global Cardiac Institute / EM Sim Cases
Recognize and manage acute myocardial infarction in patients presenting to the emergency department.
Rapid recognition and intervention in myocardial infarction can significantly improve patient outcomes and survival rates.
You are the attending in the emergency department when a 55-year-old male presents with crushing chest pain and diaphoresis.
Immediate management of acute myocardial infarction requiring aspirin and reperfusion therapy.
Busy emergency room with medical staff attending to various patients.
Monitor alarms, distant conversations, occasional announcements
Middle-aged man in distress, clutching chest, medical staff in action.
Aspirin, EKG machine, crash cart, oxygen supplies.
55M presenting with severe chest pain and unstable vitals.
Patient placed on continuous cardiac monitoring.
Immediate PCI or thrombolysis if indicated.
>5 min untreated -> increased risk of arrest.
Diaphoretic, clammy skin, left arm pain
Severe chest pain, diaphoresis, ST-elevation on EKG
Patient's brother had a heart attack at age 50.
RN: 'His vitals are dropping, we need to act fast.'
I feel like an elephant is sitting on my chest.
chest pain, MI, aspirin, EKG, PCI
{"If aspirin given": "Pain stabilizes, vitals improve", "If no intervention in 10 minutes": "Patient arrests"}
Branch: if rapid intervention â†’ recovery; else â†’ arrest
Administer aspirin, perform EKG, prepare for PCI
Administer nitroglycerin, initiate oxygen therapy, contact cardiology
Initiate CPR, defibrillation, advanced cardiac life support
Demonstrate effective management of acute myocardial infarction in emergency settings.
What is the first-line treatment for suspected myocardial infarction?
Developed to enhance rapid response skills in acute myocardial infarction cases.
